Detailed Description

Handling exact values.

Description

CMDecimal is used when dealing with exact values such as currencies.

Author:
Elliot Chance
Since:
1.0

String value.

Returns:
String value of the decimal value.

Reimplemented from CMError.

Definition at line 187 of file CMDecimal.php.

add ( $  value  ) 

Addition.

The new value will be returned, and not assigned. You must assign the value yourself like: 

 $d = new CMDecimal(8, 2, "53.78");
 $d = $d->add("13.73");
Parameters:
$value The new value can be a string or CMDecimal.
Returns:
New CMDecimal object.

Definition at line 96 of file CMDecimal.php.

CMDecimal ( $  size,
$  prec,
$  value = 0 
)

Create a decimal object.

Parameters:
$size The total size of the decimal (not including the decimal point)
$prec The precision after the decimal point.
$value An optional value to assign now. If this is not provided then 0 will be used.

Definition at line 132 of file CMDecimal.php.

set ( $  value  ) 

Set the value.

Throws a CMError Error
See CMError::throwError(). If the $value provided is to large to fit in the given $size. This function will return false.
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the $value precision is greater than that of this class and the number has to be truncated.
Parameters:
$value Can be a string or CMDecimal object.
Returns:
This object as a CMDecimal.

Definition at line 114 of file CMDecimal.php.

Field Documentation

$prec = 6 [private]

The precision after the decimal point.

This must be greater than or equal to 0. If $prec is zero then the '.' character will not be printed - in other words to treat numbers are integers.
